headline.main: 6 Medical Myths for the Holiday Season

docs.abstract: Sugar makes kids hyper? Poinsettias are poisonous? A look at some common medical myths that surface during the holidays.
docs.lead_paragraph: Last year, the British medical journal BMJ reported on a series of medical myths that even doctors believe. Among them: Turkey makes you drowsy. Dim light ruins your eyes. Drink at last eight glasses of water a day.
docs.snippet: Sugar makes kids hyper? Poinsettias are poisonous? A look at some common medical myths that surface during the holidays.

docs.abstract: My Thursday column welcomes New York State's proposed new tax on non-diet soft drinks, as a way to reduce obesity and bolster public health. I'm a firm believer that the road to health care reform doesn't involve only universal health care, but also a series of public health initiatives to improve the diet, promote exercise [...]
docs.lead_paragraph: My Thursday column welcomes New York State's proposed new tax on non-diet soft drinks, as a way to reduce obesity and bolster public health. I'm a firm believer that the road to health care reform doesn't involve only universal health care, but also a series of public health initiatives to improve the diet, promote exercise and reduce salt consumption. The cigarette tax was a huge success, and a tax on sugary drinks holds similar promise. Some other countries, including Mexico, are looking at a national soft drink tax for the same reason.
docs.snippet: My Thursday column welcomes New York State's proposed new tax on non-diet soft drinks, as a way to reduce obesity and bolster public health. I'm a firm believer that the road to health care reform doesn't involve only universal health care, but also...

headline.main: At a Brooklyn Convent, a Season of Heartbreak

docs.abstract: Also in the Morning Buzz: Governor Paterson's budget proposal, the M.T.A.'s doomsday budget and more headlines from local papers.
docs.lead_paragraph: Behind the red-brick walls encircling the Convent of Mercy in Brooklyn, generations of nuns have taught the illiterate, sheltered the homeless and raised orphans. They are known as the Walking Sisters, ministering in the community as well as inside their convent.
docs.snippet: Also in the Morning Buzz: Governor Paterson's budget proposal, the M.T.A.'s doomsday budget and more headlines from local papers.

headline.main: Soda Tax Plan Sparks a Debate

docs.abstract: The Paterson administration's proposal to charge an additional 18 percent tax on sugary sodas and juice drinks has drawn intense response.
docs.lead_paragraph: The Paterson administration's proposal to charge an 18 percent sales tax on sugary sodas and juice drinks -- an effort that state officials said would reduce obesity while raising more than $400 million a year for health programs -- has already touched off a vigorous debate among New Yorkers, nutrition experts and officials from the beverage industry, which vowed to fight the proposal.The 18 percent sales tax, which would be on top of regular sales taxes, would apply to sugary sodas and fruit drinks containing less than 70 percent natural fruit juice. The tax would not apply to bottled water, diet sodas, coffee, tea or milk.
docs.snippet: The Paterson administration's proposal to charge an additional 18 percent tax on sugary sodas and juice drinks has drawn intense response.
